Well Jason, this is my first time having a discussion with you so this should be very interesting.
 
 
Your not a true Democrat. If you were you'd actually use your brain instead of giving us who do a bad rep. As for myself I am for gun rights but I am also for gun responsibility.

 
 First and foremost, while I do support responsibility, I feel that this is a dangerous standard to try and enforce. What one person defines as responsibility, another person can easily define as totalitarian and overbearing.
 
 Case in point, let's look at the Brady Campaign's statement after the initial ruling of Parker v DC. While it doesn't talk about responsibility specifically, I feel it's a good example to illustrate the point that everyone has a different take on what something is.
 
 Parker v. District of Columbia-- Brady Campaign Blog
 
 "The decision in Parker, if upheld, could lead to all current and proposed firearms laws being called into question. This decision is wrong on the law, wrong on the history, and substitutes decision-making by elected officials with the preferences of a slim judicial majority."
 
 That's quite a position to be taking. In the pre-Heller era one could get away with a statement like that. But with context applied and what we know now, the Brady Campaign's argument was that DC's total handgun ban was the only right option to be had. They're a group that continues to talk about reasonable restrictions when it comes to gun laws, so their advocacy of DC's handgun ban, by default, could only mean that they feel it to be a reasonable restriction. And since they haven't renounced that opinion it's only safe to assume that they still feel that way; they just aren't vocalizing it.
 
 The problem with trying to normalize the idea of "gun responsibility" lies in first trying to define it in a manner that would be considered reasonable by the majority of people who it would apply to, while at the same time being enforceable in a practical manner so it amounts to more than a simple suggestion of what might be a good idea. If it's too strong then it's an unacceptable intrusion by government. If it's too weak it's useless in nature and had no justification in being passed in the first place.
 
 
The NRA and other organizations should promote safe gun handling, cleaning, maintenance, etc. if your going to exercise your right to carry a weapon such judgment and proper discretion must be paramount.

 
 While I do agree with the idea of promoting the safe handling of guns, I stop short of the notion (supported by some) that such should first be a requirement before one can legally exercise their constitutional rights in the first place. Such a notion goes back to the unconstitutional literacy tests that were used to prevent freed blacks from being able to vote in elections, which the Supreme Court found to be unconstitutional.
 
 Suggesting that someone must first prove themselves capable before they can legally enjoy a constitutional right relegates said right to the status of a government granted privilege, which enjoys no legal protection and can be revoked with little or no reason and leave the people with no legal recourse in response. It's a very dangerous precedent to be setting.
 
 
I would also like to see somehow tougher screening for gun owners as in the case of this tragedy in Tuscon. I dunno if there could some how be some sort of mental evaluation done by some outside group or whatnot but seeing how so many crazies are getting access it would be nice to see proactive steps being taken to see that only responsible grounded individuals can own weapons.

 
 Oh there is so much wrong with this. But I'll try and get to it.
 
 Firstly, I already explained to Galileo about the issue of mental health. There's no evidence that Loughner was ever committed or adjudicated as mentally deficient, meaning there was no legal documentation that carried actual weight in the manner, so there was nothing for the system to catch. Even if he had been adjudicated it wouldn't have mattered if the state was incapable of forwarding his records and making them available for the NICS background check system. And even if he did have a record and it was in the system, and he had been legally barred from buying the Glock pistol that he used, there's no reason to believe that he wouldn't have been able to bypass the system entirely by simply hiring a friend to buy the gun for him and then turn right around and give it to him in a straw purchase; something that is both hard to detect and even harder to properly define.
 
 Secondly we come to the issue of just who would be considered qualified in making the determination about one's mental stability and health, concluding who's crazy, etc. Back around the time of the Virgina Tech Shooting, where there was talk about better record keeping for mental health records, the talk eventually turned to military veterans who were barred from owning a gun because they were ruled as mentally incompetent. More discussion on this subject eventually revealed that these rulings were not made by trained medical officials who were skilled in matters of mental health and psychological well being. These veterans were ruled as mentally incompetent for the most trivial of matters even though they were able to properly function in a peace time society. Now we're trying to correct that mistake and expunge their records so they can legally enjoy their rights again without fear of imprisonment.
 
 The ease of which such a system can be abused by so-called "mental health experts" is quite scary. I won't go into detail about the evils of such a standard right now, that's best saved for later.
 
 The third point is something that a lot of people miss. One doesn't have to be mentally ill to become a psychotic killer or go on a shooting spree. There's unfortunately no set profile or markers to indicate who will kill and who won't. High profile examples notwithstanding, there are too many examples where somebody without any sign of serious mental illness simply went and killed others for no recognizable reason. There's nothing to prevent one who is judged as mentally well balanced from later committing criminal acts at some point possibly years or decades down the line, long after they were green stamped as safe.
 
 One could try and suggest follow up evaluations as an option so gun owners are periodically re-certified as being safe and mentally well balanced and properly grounded, but that would have the potential to open up a can of worms to civil litigation on the basis of discriminatory practices, inconsistent standards of application, unfair observation, infringement on constitutionally recognized rights, etc. It's simply an impossible standard to try and implement.
